reference: Volume Four, Issue Forty-One, File 1 of 13
title: Phrack 41
authors: Dispater, The Racketeer, Scott Simpson, The Cavalier, VaxBuster, Bobby Zero, Caligula XXI, Datastream Cowboy
historical_context: This issue marks the last one edited by Dispater, reflecting on the evolution of the hacking community and the challenges faced by its members.
target_audience: Hackers, phreakers, security professionals, and those interested in hacker culture.
short_summary: Phrack 41 features a farewell from editor Dispater, a response to community feedback, and various articles covering hacking techniques, security vulnerabilities, and profiles of notable figures in the hacking scene.
summary: In this pivotal issue of Phrack, editor Dispater bids farewell, citing personal challenges and a waning interest in the editorial role. He reflects on the community's evolution and the importance of exposing security flaws to challenge the status quo. The issue includes a Loopback section addressing reader feedback and contributions from various authors, including The Racketeer, who continues his Network Miscellany column with insights on fake mail. The Phrack Pro-Phile section delves into the enigmatic figure of Supernigger, offering wisdom for those in the hacker scene. The issue also features technical articles on hacking AT&T's System 75, building a DMS-10 switch, and TTY spoofing, showcasing the diverse interests and skills within the hacking community. Overall, Phrack 41 serves as a reflection on the past and a look toward the future of hacking culture.
additional_notes: This issue encapsulates the spirit of the early 90s hacker culture, emphasizing the importance of information sharing and the critique of traditional security practices.
